summary: This document is an email chain from April 2020 among U.S. Attorney's Office personnel and others, discussing significant logistical and technical problems with processing and reviewing electronic evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's properties. The emails focus on the lack of proper documentation for seized devices, difficulties linking emails to attachments, and issues with data load files, hindering the review of over 1 million documents.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The entire email chain concerns the processing and review of electronic evidence seized from his properties in New York and the Virgin Islands.

events.title: Prior property search
events.description: Mention of a July 2007 search on one of Jeffrey Epstein's properties, where hard drives were seized that were later found copied in his Manhattan apartment in 2019.

events.title: Search of Epstein properties
events.description: Search warrants executed at Epstein's New York mansion and Virgin Islands residence, resulting in the seizure of numerous electronic devices including computers, hard drives, thumb drives, CDs, and servers.

locations: Southern District of New York (US Attorney's Office)
keyFacts: Over 1 million documents were seized from Epstein's properties, but the review was hampered by severe technical and organizational issues.
Evidence included 9 IDE hard drives from a 2007 search found copied in the NY apartment, over 40 devices from NY, over 25 devices from the Virgin Islands (including servers), and at least 60+ CDs.
A major problem was the inability to link emails to their attachments in the received data, making review and future production to defense counsel extremely difficult.
The data load files had control numbers that did not match the native files, and there was no link between them, rendering many large files 'completely invisible' to reviewers.

The correspondence reveals ongoing frustration and a lack of basic inventory ('a very basic list of each device or item that was seized and searched') nearly two months after the evidence was requested.
